articles.title: EPHEMERIS
articles.summary: This document, titled "EPHEMERIS," dates to November 1983 and appears to be associated with an organization abbreviated as SJAA. It features an image of an astronomical nebula, suggesting it likely contains information about celestial events, observations, or positions for that month.

articles.title: UPCOMING EVENTS
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) has scheduled star parties for November 5th and December 3rd at a new dark-sky location, J.D. Grant Ranch County Park. Their General Meeting on November 12th will feature NASA's Jeff Scargle discussing the detection of extra-solar planets. Additionally, a planned grazing occultation expedition for November 13th is proceeding with caution due to uncertainties regarding a double-star target.

articles.title: CLUB TELESCOPES
articles.summary: The SJAA (San Jose Astronomical Association) offers a telescope loan program for its members, providing access to three different telescopes: a 6" Newtonian, a 12" Dobsonian, and a 14" f/6 Dobsonian. Loan periods are two months, with extensions possible if there's no demand, and members are asked to notify a board member or editor when a telescope changes hands. Contact information for current telescope holders is provided.

articles.title: ENDING NOTES
articles.summary: The editor of the monthly Ephemeris thanks contributors, apologizes for last month's late bulletin, and requests more articles and black and white astronomy photographs. Additionally, a member named Bill is seeking volunteers to help move a Cassegrain/refractor telescope from his parents' garage.

articles.title: ADS
articles.summary: This document features several classified advertisements for used astronomical equipment, including Celestron C-5 and C-8 telescopes, various eyepieces, filters, mounts, and accessories. It also includes instructions for members of SJAA and friends on how to place free astronomically-related ads in the Ephemeris newsletter, noting they run for two months.

articles.title: BY DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: The article reports on six comets observed in the past month, comprising three new discoveries (IRAS, Shoemaker, and Kowal-Vávrová) and three recoveries of periodic comets (Arend, Harrington-Abell, and Wild). It details their discovery circumstances, current magnitudes, and future visibility prospects, noting that most will remain faint, with Comet Cernis continuing to fade.

articles.title: PAST DISCOVERIES
articles.summary: The article details the discovery circumstances of three comets: Bowell (1975n), Sato (1975q), and Meier (1980n). For each, it outlines the discoverer, date, magnitude, and celestial coordinates at the time of discovery. A significant portion is dedicated to exploring potential reasons why these comets remained undetected for periods prior to their actual discovery, citing factors such as faintness, celestial background (e.g., Milky Way), rapid brightening, or lack of observers in certain regions.

articles.title: Comet Ephemeris
articles.summary: This document provides an ephemeris for Comet Cernis (1983L), detailing its Right Ascension, Declination, and estimated magnitude for dates from late October to mid-December. It notes the comet is receding into deep space, approximately 3.5 AU from the Sun, and may be brighter than the predicted 10th-11th magnitude range, with data sourced from Circular 3869.

articles.title: COMPARISON TESTS of NEW POLAROID 35mm AUTOPROCESS FILM
articles.summary:
# COMPARISON TESTS of NEW POLAROID 35mm AUTOPROCESS FILM
by Jack Marling

Polaroid has introduced a new 35mm auto process slide film. Called Polaroid Polagraph 35mm film, it is developedinto a slide i...

articles.title: Table 1 - Film Speed Comparison in 20 Minute Exposures
articles.summary: This article presents a comparison of film speeds for various films, including Polaroid HC-1, Kodak Technical Pan 2415, Ektachrome 400, and Fujichrome 400, in 20-minute exposures for deep-sky astrophotography. It concludes that Fujichrome 400 is highly recommended due to its superior speed, particularly in the H-Alpha red spectrum, enabling incredible detail in faint nebulosity. Conversely, Polaroid HC-1 is deemed unsuitable for deep-sky work due to severe reciprocity failure, though it may suit brighter objects.

articles.title: Commercial ads are priced according to size and may be placed by contacting:
articles.summary: This document specifies that commercial advertisements are priced based on their size. Interested parties can place an ad by contacting Gene Cisneros at the provided phone number, (408) 923-6800.

articles.title: LUMICON®
articles.summary: Lumicon promotes itself as a "World Center for Astrophotography" and a primary retailer for in-stock telescopes and accessories in the Western US, based in Livermore, CA. The advertisement showcases their "Innovation in Astronomy" by featuring an astrophotography image of the Hale Nebula NGC2239, which was captured using a LUMICON Deep-Sky H-Beta NB filter and "LUMICON Mode," demonstrating the capabilities of their specialized products.

articles.title: ATA coatings
articles.summary: ATA Coatings specializes in applying aluminum coatings with a silicon monoxide over-coating for telescope mirrors, offering a price list for various mirror sizes. The service includes free secondary mirror recoating when sent with a primary mirror, and charges for old coating removal, with a minimum service fee. Customers are responsible for return postage and insurance.

articles.title: OPTRON SYSTEMS
articles.summary: Optron Systems is a retailer located in San Jose, CA, offering a wide range of astronomy equipment and accessories from various brands such as Bushnell, Celestron, Meade, and Tele-Vue Optics. They invite customers to visit their showroom.

articles.title: CALENDAR
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) outlines its calendar of activities from November to January, featuring a variety of events for members and the public. These include multiple outdoor star parties at J.D. Grant Ranch County Park, indoor star parties at the Los Gatos Red Cross building, and general meetings at the University of Santa Clara. Highlights include a lecture on the detection of extra-solar planets and opportunities to use new telescopes.

articles.title: General meetings:
articles.summary: This document provides detailed directions to the "General meetings" held at the University of Santa Clara's Alumni Science Hall, room 102. It includes instructions for those traveling north or south on Hwy 17, as well as parking information and specific room access details within the building.

articles.title: Indoor Star Parties:
articles.summary:
## Indoor Star Parties:

Los Gatos Red Cross Building, 18011 Los Gatos-Saratoga Rd., Los Gatos

From Hwy 17 south take the Hwy 9 (Saratoga) exit and continue up Los Gatos-Saratoga Rd. for about 1.5 mi...

articles.title: Henry Coe State Park:
articles.summary: This document provides detailed directions to the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) observing site within Henry Coe State Park. It outlines the route from Hwy 101, landmarks such as Anderson Reservoir, and specific instructions for locating and accessing a locked gate with a provided combination. Important rules for after-dark arrival, including parking outside the gate and using parking lights only, are also included.

articles.title: Fremont Peak State Park:
articles.summary: This document provides detailed driving directions to Fremont Peak State Park, starting from Hwy 101 South towards Salinas. It specifies the route to the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) setup area at Coulter Camp overflow and includes a reminder about parking light etiquette after dark.

articles.title: BY BOB FINGERHUT
articles.summary: The article details various contemporary space activities, including the delay of the Spacelab 1 mission (STS-9/Columbia) due to a solid propellant motor issue, while outlining its scientific objectives and crew. It also reports on successful launches and satellite deployments by ESA, India, and other nations, as well as Soviet probes entering Venus's orbit. Additionally, the document highlights two significant Soviet space incidents: a booster explosion from which cosmonauts safely escaped, and a critical propellant leak on the Salyut 7 space station that severely limited its operational capabilities.

articles.title: Manned Maneuvering Units Delivered
articles.summary: NASA has received two Manned Maneuvering Units (MMUs) for upcoming Space Shuttle missions. These units are intended for use on Mission 11, scheduled for January 19, 1984, and Mission 13, which is the Solar Maximum satellite repair mission set for April 4, 1984.

articles.title: Space Telescope Instrument Delivered for Testing
articles.summary: The Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) has delivered the wide field and planetary camera, an instrument for a space telescope, to the Goddard Space Flight Center. This delivery marks a significant step, as the instrument will now undergo testing at the Goddard facility.

articles.title: Senate Opposes Satellite Sale
articles.summary: The Senate unanimously passed a non-binding resolution disapproving the Reagan Administration's plan to sell Earth remote-sensing satellites to private industry. This action is significant as the sale requires specific legislation from both houses of Congress, effectively halting the proposed transaction.

articles.title: Plans to Store Columbia Reversed
articles.summary: NASA Administrator James M. Beggs has reversed an earlier decision to store the orbiter Columbia for two years and potentially use it for spare parts after its Spacelab 1 mission. Beggs criticized the previous plan as unsound political and engineering policy.

articles.title: THE 1983 AMERICAN WORKSHOP on COMETARY ASTRONOMY by Don Machholz
articles.summary: The 1983 American Workshop on Cometary Astronomy, hosted at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, California, gathered over 130 comet enthusiasts for various talks and tours. The workshop featured presentations by both JPL staff on topics like cometary photometry and spacecraft missions, and amateur astronomers discussing photography, filters, and visual observing techniques, all with a significant focus on Halley's Comet. A key announcement indicated that Halley's Comet might be two magnitudes brighter than initially predicted for its 1986 apparition.

articles.title: SJAA COMPUTER
articles.summary: This article details the development of a computer system for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA), funded by two grants and led by Bruce DeGraaf. Originating from an SJAA charge injection device (CID) camera project, the system uses an Atari 400 computer and is designed for low cost, long-term reliability without moving parts, and ease of use through 'canned' cartridge programs. The project faced challenges, including the theft of initial equipment, which necessitated repurchasing components and acquiring new grants.

articles.title: Programs
articles.summary: The document outlines three planned computer programs. It notes that their development may be time-consuming, and one of the programs currently faces a known technical issue.

articles.title: Camera control
articles.summary: This document details the development of a camera control program for a CID camera, featuring a custom interface to digitize its 128x128 sensor output for a 400 system. The system processes both actual and noise images to enhance dim light capability, requiring significant memory, and supports exposure times from 1/15 to four seconds with flicker-free TV display. It is designed for astrophotographic guiding and public presentations, with an option to generate hard copies via an 822 thermal printer.

articles.title: Other programs
articles.summary: This article evaluates the Atari 400's suitability as a word processor, specifically for managing an 'Ephemeris'. It identifies significant drawbacks, including the 822 printer's narrow paper, the necessity and fragility of mass storage like a diskette drive, and the poor quality of the Atari 400's built-in keyboard, which the author strongly criticizes.

articles.title: MEMBERSHIP
articles.summary: This document discusses the practicality of different keyboards, noting the standard 400's advantage for field work due to easy cleaning, unlike the B-Key 400. It then outlines three inexpensive applications for a new device: a camera controller, an occultation aid, and an auction controller. The author also suggests that while a word processor is useful, a program development package isn't necessary for the SJAA, proposing seeking grants for 'word-smithing' activities.

articles.title: MEMBERSHIP
articles.summary: This document outlines the process for membership renewal, instructing members to send their renewal form, payment, and a Sky & Telescope notice card (if applicable) to Bob Fingerhut, the Treasurer of SJAA. The article provides his full mailing address in Milpitas, California, and a contact phone number for assistance.

articles.title: SJAA MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION/RENEWAL
articles.summary: This document serves as a membership application and renewal form for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA), detailing various membership tiers and their costs, including options with or without an 'EPHEMERIS' subscription. It also provides a comprehensive list of the association's officers and board of directors, along with their contact information.

articles.title: TIME VALUE — DATED
articles.summary: This document displays a postal indicia for a 'BULK RATE' mailing by 'SIAA «PREMIERE»' from San Jose, CA. The 'TIME VALUE — DATED' notation suggests the content of the mailed item is time-sensitive, likely indicating a newsletter, announcement, or similar communication with a limited relevance period.
